word.entryDescription: continuously in the same direction
word.entryExample: Go straight on until you get to a big road, and then turn left.

word.entryDescription: unable to leave a place due to a problem
word.entryExample: I missed my flight and was left stranded in Kinshasa!

word.entryDescription: a plan or method of achieving something, especially social or political
word.entryExample: The Metropolitan Police have an exciting, new community police strategy.

word.entryDescription: the dried stems of cereal plants after the grain has been removed, often used as something for animals to sleep on, to make things, etc
word.entryExample: Thatched roofs are made of straw.

word.entryDescription: a small juicy red fruit which grows on a low plant
word.entryExample: I'd like strawberry ice cream, please.

word.entryDescription: a road that usually has buildings on its sides
word.entryExample: I live in the longest street in my town.

word.entryDescription: to make stronger
word.entryExample: Some postures are intended to stretch and strengthen muscles.

word.entryDescription: the feeling of being worried or anxious all the time
word.entryExample: You should try to reduce stress as much as possible.

word.entryDescription: so worried or anxious that you are unable to relax
word.entryExample: Why do you look so stressed and tired?

word.entryDescription: to fully extend your arms, legs, muscles, etc
word.entryExample: Stretch your arms away from the body, reach, relax and then do the same things with your legs.

word.entryDescription: to become bigger or looser, to make something bigger or looser
word.entryExample: My jumper stretched so much I could have worn it as a dress!

word.entryDescription: an event when people stop working because they are unhappy about something at work
word.entryExample: We were checking in when we saw the sign – the baggage-handlers were on strike!

word.entryDescription: having a pattern of long thick or thin lines
word.entryExample: William is wearing shorts with a striped t-shirt.

word.entryDescription: a sudden serious condition in which part of the brain stops functioning due to a loss of blood supply caused by a blockage or bleeding
word.entryExample: Have you any idea of how you can tell if someone has had a stroke?

word.entryDescription: physically powerful
word.entryExample: Who is strong in your family?

word.entryDescription: to use a lot of effort in trying to deal with something difficult
word.entryExample: I've been struggling to write this essay all evening.

word.entryDescription: decorated with small raised pieces of metal, e.g. studs or small jewels
word.entryExample: Emos often wear tight jeans, band t-shirts and studded belts.

word.entryDescription: somebody who studies
word.entryExample: There are enough computers in this classroom for every student in the class to have one.

word.entryDescription: a room in which music is recorded or television or radio programmes are made
word.entryExample: After the rehearsal, Alan, the guitarist, said that he liked my voice and that I should come to the recording studio with them.

word.entryDescription: to work at learning something
word.entryExample: She was made to study all weekend.

word.entryDescription: the state of being stunned; shock
word.entryExample: It took him a few seconds to recover from the stun.

word.entryDescription: extremely beautiful
word.entryExample: The view from the top is stunning!

word.entryDescription: a particular form or design of something, especially clothes, hair, etc
word.entryExample: There are a number of different styles of street fashion.

word.entryDescription: attractive and fashionable
word.entryExample: My sister loves dressing up in stylish clothes.

word.entryDescription: a particular area of study
word.entryExample: My favourite school subject is maths.

word.entryDescription: to translate the actors' words into a foreign language and write them at the bottom of the screen
word.entryExample: He told me he preferred to watch subtitled films.

word.entryDescription: a mainly residential area of a city which is away from the centre
word.entryExample: I prefer living in the suburbs to living in the city centre.

word.entryDescription: when the desired result is achieved
word.entryExample: Homeopathy, the practice of giving patients a small dose of what is causing their problem, has had some success in treating common allergies.

word.entryDescription: having achieved the desired result, or having done very well in something
word.entryExample: The successful candidate will be working in a number of different departments.

word.entryDescription: used when giving an example of something
word.entryExample: Many organisations, such as Amnesty International, say there is no evidence that the death penalty stops criminals from committing crimes.

word.entryDescription: quickly and without being expected
word.entryExample: Suddenly, the door opened and I saw an old woman.

word.entryDescription: to take legal action against a person, organisation, etc, usually to try to get money in exchange for harm or difficulty they have caused you
word.entryExample: In 2008, the British band Coldplay were sued by a guitarist who accused the band of copying parts of one of his songs.

word.entryDescription: to experience pain or something unpleasant
word.entryExample: People who got this disease suffered from painful swellings.

word.entryDescription: a sweet powder made from a plant which you add to food and drinks
word.entryExample: There's a lot of sugar in the cake.

word.entryDescription: to mention an idea as advice
word.entryExample: I suggest taking a cushion to sit on.

word.entryDescription: an idea for what could be done that somebody mentions
word.entryExample: If you have any suggestions, please email me.

word.entryDescription: a formal item of clothing consisting of a jacket and trousers
word.entryExample: My cousin's getting married and he's going to wear a suit.

word.entryDescription: to look good on
word.entryExample: Red suits you. You look good in it.

word.entryDescription: right for a particular person, use or situation
word.entryExample: High-heeled shoes aren't suitable for running in.

word.entryDescription: a big bag with a handle in which you carry your things when you travel
word.entryExample: I'm going to pack my suitcase before you change your mind!

word.entryDescription: a poisonous gas with a strong, unpleasant smell
word.entryExample: Some of the other gases that are released when fossil fuels are burned, like sulphur dioxide, can pollute the air.

word.entryDescription: used to introduce a conclusion of a speech, report, etc.
word.entryExample: To sum up, if you need to lose weight you should avoid fad diets and take regular exercise.

word.entryDescription: the large bright object in the sky which gives us light and heat
word.entryExample: The sun is shining.

word.entryDescription: the day between Saturday and Monday
word.entryExample: We have dinner at our grandparents' every Sunday.

word.entryDescription: dark glasses that you wear in bright sunshine
word.entryExample: Don't forget your sunglasses. It's going to be very sunny.

word.entryDescription: having a lot of light from the sun
word.entryExample: It's sunny - let's have a barbecue.

word.entryDescription: the direct light and heat of the sun
word.entryExample: Fig trees like plenty of sunshine and not much wind.

word.entryDescription: excellent; extremely good
word.entryExample: That was the most superb film I've seen in ages!

word.entryDescription: a fast road with several lanes in the USA
word.entryExample: Who will build this expensive new superhighway?

word.entryDescription: a superlative adjective or adverb expresses the highest degree of something
word.entryExample: The superlative form of 'tall' is 'tallest'.
